title: Common Cold
content: A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract. Symptoms include runny nose, sore throat, cough, congestion, sneezing, mild fever, and body aches. Duration is typically 7-10 days. Treatment includes rest, staying hydrated, over-the-counter pain relievers, saline nasal drops, and warm liquids. Medical treatment may include antiviral medications and prescription decongestants in severe cases. Prevention involves frequent hand washing, avoiding close contact with sick people, not touching face with unwashed hands, and maintaining good immune system health. Possible complications include sinus infection, ear infection, bronchitis, and rarely pneumonia.

title: Influenza (Flu)
content: A contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. Symptoms include high fever, severe body aches, fatigue, dry cough, sore throat, headache, and chills. Duration is typically 1-2 weeks. Treatment includes rest, staying hydrated, over-the-counter pain relievers, and antiviral medications if prescribed. Medical treatment may include antiviral medications within 48 hours of symptoms and hospitalization in severe cases. Prevention involves annual flu vaccination, frequent hand washing, avoiding close contact with sick people, and staying home when sick. Complications can include pneumonia, bronchitis, sinus infections, ear infections, and worsening of chronic conditions. Urgent warning signs include difficulty breathing, chest pain, sudden dizziness, severe vomiting, and confusion.

title: Hypertension (High Blood Pressure)
content: A condition where the force of blood against artery walls is too high. Usually asymptomatic, but may cause headaches, shortness of breath, and rarely nosebleeds. Blood pressure categories: Normal (less than 120/80 mmHg), Elevated (120-129/<80 mmHg), Stage 1 (130-139/80-89 mmHg), Stage 2 (140 or higher/90 or higher mmHg), Crisis (higher than 180/higher than 120 mmHg). Treatment includes lifestyle changes such as healthy diet (DASH diet), regular exercise, weight management, limiting alcohol, quitting smoking, and reducing sodium intake. Medications may include diuretics, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, calcium channel blockers, and beta blockers. Risk factors include age, family history, obesity, physical inactivity, high sodium diet, excessive alcohol consumption, and stress. Complications can include heart attack, stroke, heart failure, kidney disease, and vision loss.
